    microbiome-demo

    microbiome-demo.Rmd
    library(alto)
library(dplyr)
library(magrittr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tibble)
library(stringr)
library(tidyr)

    This document showcases the alto package functions applied to vaginal microbiome data.

    Loading the data

    We use the data published with the article “Replication and refinement of a vaginal microbial signature of preterm birth in two racially distinct cohorts of US women” by Calahan et al., 2017, PNAS.

    A .zip file containing the related data can be downloaded from the Stanford data catalog.

    For convenience, the data file (i.e. the tables contained in the processed.rda file) has been attached to the alto package as vm_data. For details, type ?vm_data.

    names(vm_data)

    First, we do some pre-processing of the data. Specifically, we change the colnames to replace ASV sequences by human-friendly names built from the taxonomy table.

    
# we create the human-friendly ASV names
# by concatenating Genus and Species and an identifying number
# as a given species can be represented by several ASVs
vm_data$taxonomy <-
  vm_data$taxonomy %>%
  as.data.frame() %>%
  group_by(Genus, Species) %>%
  mutate(
    ASV_name =
      paste0(
        ifelse(is.na(Genus),"[unknown Genus]", Genus), " ",
        ifelse(is.na(Species),"[unknown Species]", Species), " ",
        row_number()
        )
    ) %>%
  ungroup()

# then, we replace the colnames of the count matrix by these new names.
# Note that the tax table rows are ordered as the count matrix columns,
# allowing us to assign without matching first.
colnames(vm_data$counts) = vm_data$taxonomy$ASV_name

    Using alto on these data

    Our first step is to run the lda models for varying number of topics, i.e. from 2 to 15 topics. For this, we use the run_lda_models function. This can take a while on a personal computer. For example, it takes about x minutes on the authors’ laptops.

    
lda_varying_params_lists = list()
for (k in 1:12) {lda_varying_params_lists[[paste0("k",k)]] = list(k = k)}

lda_models =
  run_lda_models(
    data = vm_data$counts[1:100,1:50], # change for the full data set when full workflow is ready
    lda_varying_params_lists = lda_varying_params_lists,
    lda_fixed_params_list = list(method = "VEM"),
    verbose = TRUE
  )

    We can now align the topics from each consecutive models:

    

aligned_topics =
  align_topics(
    models = lda_models,
    comparison = "consecutive",
    method = "product") # transport product

aligned_topics@weights %>% head()

aligned_topics_lsy =
  align_topics(
    models = lda_models,
    comparison = "consecutive",
    method = "product",
    order_version = "lsy")

    And visualize the alignment:

    
plot_alignment(aligned_topics, color_by = "b")

plot_alignment(aligned_topics_lsy, color_by = "b")

    Alignment with diagnostics scores

    
plot_alignment(aligned_topics_lsy, color_by = "r")

plot_alignment(aligned_topics_lsy, color_by = "s")

    Diagnostics

    
compute_number_of_key_topics(weights = aligned_topics@weights, plot = TRUE)
    
stability =
  compute_stability_along_branches(
    aligned_topics@weights
  )

ggplot(stability, aes(x = m, y = branch, fill = stability)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "red", high = "blue")
    
refinement <-
  compute_refinement_scores(
    aligned_topics@weights
  )

ggplot(refinement,
       aes(x = m, y = k_LDA, fill = refinement_score)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "red", high = "blue")
